description:
Brucella oryzae is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Brucella. Brucella species are known to be the causative agents of brucellosis, a zoonotic disease that can infect both humans and animals.

Brucella oryzae is a Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, aerobic bacterium. It is a facultative intracellular pathogen, meaning it can survive and replicate within the host's cells. The bacterium is typically rod-shaped and exhibits a characteristic smooth colony morphology when grown on culture media.

The natural host and reservoir of Brucella oryzae is not well-established, but it has been isolated from rice plants (Oryza sativa) and soil samples. The specific mechanisms by which Brucella oryzae infects and interacts with plants are not fully understood, but it is believed to have some adaptations that allow it to colonize and survive in the plant environment.

While Brucella oryzae has been reported in limited studies, its potential to cause disease in humans or animals is not well-documented. Further research is needed to better understand the epidemiology, pathogenicity, and public health significance of this Brucella species.
